title: Do some homeless people enjoy the homeless lifestyle? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my experience I would say there are some that choose it, and many that don’t exactly “choose” it, by default end up choosing it by life choices, etc. Sadly I have not had too many experiences helping people that have ended successfully, but have had a few. I have worked with many homeless over the years, in different capacities. My first real experience was as a young pastors wife. I was all of 20 years old. A family came to the church looking for help, and I went to our board and asked for more assistance than our normal, which was a few food vouchers, vouchers for a hotel for 3 nights, and some bags of food. This was a mom, dad, three children, and mom was pregnant. They had traveled several states, and they were out of money, and car was broken down. Dad seemed willing to work. Mom was clearly not 100% with it mentally, but cleared loved her children. She received social security due to her handicap, but had not been receiving it due to having no address. Our group took special offerings, collected enough money to set them up in an apartment, nothing fancy, but not roach infested. We put down first and last, set up all their utilities, groceries, etc. People donated everything to set up household, furniture, bedding, kitchen, some men in our church repaired their car. Mom especially was thrilled, even though everything was used and mis-matched, it was the nicest she had ever had. I was helping them daily get things organized, set up, doing shopping, taking her to a doctor, getting her social security disability payments set up so she could receive. We found the dad some day work, just families hiring him for yard work, etc, and trying to help him find a permanent job. We did not hand them the money, but took them shopping when they needed things. This bothered them, you could tell they wanted to have control of the money. They knew we had not spent all we collected. We told them we planned to pay the second months rent, but they would need to be prepared by the next month to pay their rent and utilities, which was a reasonable expectation. We stressed they needed to be saving what money they had coming in for that. Mom was keeping the apartment up. She had never really learned to cook, so I was helping teaching her some cooking skills. She could not really read, so recipes were difficult. We spent time working on budgeting, and how to determine what they would need to save to pay for rent and utilities, etc. We were wrapping things up with the family as my husband and I were moving soon, and someone else was going to be taking over helping the family. They were becoming a bit more independent each day. I had been assisting daily, and my husband and I took a day off to go to Disneyland before we moved. I made sure they had what they needed for the day, telling them we wouldn’t be by that day. The next thing we knew, they were calling the church and claiming that we took “their” money and went to Disneyland!! Of course they knew we had not, and calmed them down. Fast forward husband and I moved to another state, and another church member took over overseeing the family. The husband got a full time job, and things appeared to be going okay. Of course once they were making their own money, we had no say so over that, but they were encouraged to be sure to put away for the upcoming rent and utilities. As time went on, they were no longer having daily help, but mom would come by for help getting to drs. appointments, etc, while dad was working, and they were still being given some groceries to help out. Sad to say, I get a phone call about a month later. They never paid the 3rd months rent, instead using the last month that we had paid. The local liquor store let the dad run a “tab”, and he rang up quite a beer bill. By the fourth month when next rent was due, they had skipped town, leaving a trashed apartment full of beer cans, trash, and a big mess. They took whatever they could fit in the car. It was so terribly sad, as I’m sure it was the first chance this mom would ever have to have a home for her family. I really felt like it was a family that we could help and make a difference in their lives, and maybe break the cycle, but unfortunately they were unable to make the changes needed to change things. So while they would probably say they didn’t “chose” homelessness, their lack of discipline, choices they made, addictions, and disabilities all played a part in their choices.

Melinda's answer hits the nail on the head as always, and I think I add only a little perspective from personal experience. Enjoy is generally the wrong word for the way the homeless feel about their lives, but there is a real sense of pride and dignity attached to it. Being homeless is terribly hard and those who have the strength to endure it with dignity have reason to be proud of it. A few years ago I was doing some volunteer work for the homeless outreach program at my father's church. One winter night the temperature in New York was dropping down to around 0° Fahrenheit and a local church turned their auditorium into a makeshift shelter for the night with cots and blankets. I helped go around to try to convince any homeless people to come in for the night, for their own safety as much as anything else. When it gets that cold, frostbite and hypothermia become serious and pronounced risks for those on the street. When I set out, I knew that I might face some level of resistance from the people I was trying to help. Many who are homeless have been abused and mistreated in the past and I was aware that they might not trust that my intentions were pure. I had a whole speech ready about how we would absolutely not charge them any money, take anything from them, or force them to do anything against their will. Many didn't need such convincing and were instantly grateful for the offer. Others were very skeptical, but managed to be convinced. Then there was Lawrence. I had met Lawrence a couple years previous while busking in Central Park. He had been very friendly and had sat and sung a few songs with me on that occasion. He had a beautiful tenor that worked really well with my baritone voice. When he left, he’d refused my offer that he take some of the money I had made while he was singing with me, instead insisting that he put a dollar in my case. (As a street/subway performer in New York, it is amazing how common this is. Homeless people frequently give me donations despite the fact that I normally play in a tie and often have a sign saying that I am employed and not at all desperate. I have learned to just say thank you and accept it.) I had seen Lawrence several times since and he always greeted me with a smile. On the frigid night in question, I was very happy to find him. He had constructed a cardboard wall to protect his spot from the wind and he was only wearing a sweatshirt with a blazer over it and jeans. I was certain that he'd accept, given the fact that we had a previous relationship and that he was so ill-equipped to make it through the night. I was wrong. He greeted me by name and with a smile as he always did. I will never forget that conversation and I will try to convey his exact words in bold. I informed him that I had a free place to spend the night inside and that it came with two complimentary meals and a shower as well. With a big smile he just said, “Naw man, I’m good. That's really nice of you to offer, though. Thanks.” I think my face must have shown how confused I was. I went into my whole spiel about how I wasn't trying to take anything and all that. He simply replied, “Thanks but I’m okay. I've been cold before. I'll make it through this.” I asked if there was anything I could do to prove my good intentions. I also asked if he remembered having sung with me previously. “Of course I remember, Tom.” He then proceeded to sing the chorus of “Ain't No Sunshine”, one of the songs we had sung together. “I know you ain't trying to do nothing, but I'm alright out here. I don't have much but what I have, I earned. I never begged for nothin’ and I ain't planning to now.” I asserted that this was not begging but rather I was making an offer to a friend and there was nothing pathetic about accepting a gift. I reminded him that I had accepted his dollar before and that, if anything, I owed him one. “No, you earned that dollar. I ain't earned what you're trying to give me. All I got in this world is my dignity and this corner of the sidewalk. Won't never be cold enough for me to give that up.” I continued to explain that there was nothing undignified about accepting help but I realized that it was futile. I had a couple blankets in the car and insisted that he take one, but he refused saying that he had one already. Even after my insistence that this would be a “two-blanket kind of night”, he still politely refused, smiling all the time. Lawrence was stubborn as shit. I finally left the blanket folded near him and said that if he knew anyone who needed it he make sure they got it, and he was willing to agree to that. That experience taught me a lot about the homeless. Anyone who says they're all just lazy and looking for a handout has never taken the time to interact with them much. Enjoy is the wrong word, but many homeless are proud to have the strength to endure their daily struggles. They often have a great deal of dignity and a serious moral code. I hope this helps you to understand them a little bit better.

I see that the question has been changed since I answered it. I did not answer a question so stupid as to ask whether homeless people enjoy being homeless; I answered a question asking why homeless people would refuse assistance. Most homeless people don’t choose to be homeless. Even addicts, who allow their addiction to override everything else in their lives including preventing a descent into homelessness would probably rather have a real home than to be sleeping outside or in a homeless shelter. But do they refuse assistance? They don’t refuse assistance without good reasons. Often the so-called assistance comes at a cost. Staying in a shelter means they must share a room with dozens of other homeless people and risk being robbed while they sleep - if they can sleep with 30 other nearby people snoring, farting, talking to themselves. To stay in that shelter, they may have to put themselves in a sleazy part of town (because shelters aren’t in nice, safe neighborhoods) near nighttime with no guarantee that they will get a bed. They may have to turn in their personal possessions for “safekeeping.” They may be expected to shower in the same room as others, giving up their privacy. They may be charged money to sleep in these places. They will be locked in all night, and they’ll have to leave at daybreak. Then they’re stuck in the same crappy area all day unless they walk a far distance to get to a better neighborhood. When night comes, they’ll only have to walk back again. Some communities require staying at a shelter before they will provide any services at all to a homeless person. Someone unwilling to do this won’t be referred to transitional housing, won’t be helped to get on waiting lists for public housing, etc. Most people and places offer food. Of course, homeless people have nowhere to store and cook food, so they can’t carry much with them, and what they do carry needs to be edible without refrigeration and cooking. Food offered isn’t always of the highest quality, and when a person needs a shower or just a place to lie down, food isn’t a substitute for that. What else are homeless people offered that they might not accept? Younger women might be offered a place to stay - in exchange for sexual favors. Or that might not be explicitly stated, but since such offers generally come from men, they risk rape and abuse for going off with them. Religious salvation is another “offer.” This certainly occasionally gives comfort and hope to someone, but it’s not a place to sleep, a shower, a change of clothes. Help getting government benefits is another one. You’d think a homeless person would want money for disability, food stamps, Medicaid, but some are definitely on the run, avoiding criminal charges and maybe collectors or their families. Underage teens are an example of this last one. And often the things offered aren’t in good condition. Yes, there’s a room or an apartment, but it’s infested with roaches, bedbugs, mice. Yes, there are donated clothes, but they’re in poor condition and may not fit properly. Yes, there are free government cell phones, but to get one you must give your personal information to someone overseas and who knows if your calls are monitored? (They may not be, but someone may be paranoid about this or may have a legitimate fear.) I’m not saying people should refuse assistance, but usually when people do, it’s for a good reason.

Do some homeless people enjoy the homeless lifestyle? Found this question via Julia Pugliese's answer to What was your biggest “I never thought of it in that way before!” moment? (Thanks to Melinda for your help in correcting the link to Julia’s answer!) Originally I posted a long, too long!, comment to Julia’s reply, but then thought perhaps I had relevant thoughts to answer this question, “Do some homeless people enjoy the homeless lifestyle?” (EDIT: initially I intended to excerpt the bulk of my comment here, but decided to just go with freshly written reply, instead.) Here goes!  My background and understanding of homeless people is based on a combination of past volunteer work with clients of various homeless services organizations plus having an extended social circle that included several different individuals who struggled with various combinations of drug addiction, incarceration, poverty, (severe and untreated) mental illness, as well as homelessness. What I write here is primarily on my personal experiences and relationships, however limited and relevant. The short answer is that none of the homeless persons I’ve dealt with enjoy homelessness. It may appear that some may seem comfortable, or confident in their homeless state. For the most part, the sense of being comfortable for those who are chronically homeless, it is a mental and emotional adaptive change that is an indication they are coping to homelessness. Being (or at least appearing) confident is an inherently important survival tactic, if not necessarily conscious and deliberate in some situations; homeless persons that are clearly anxious or unstable can become easy prey to violent and malicious predators, as well as strangers in general who perceive homeless persons with poor attitudes. A tangential issue that I think is an assumption made by the initial question: do homeless individuals deliberately choose to be homeless? Given an option, most all homeless would not be homeless, but it is the least heinous choice based on whatever seeming options they may have. What have been the options of some of the people I’ve known? Typically their options are: Public Shelters - typically overcrowded and well-reputed to be poorly supervised and dangerous. Even if someone can get a bed, they are run not much better than a jail at times and any (perceived or actual) infraction can have a shelter resident kicked out.Hospitalization - whether for psychiatric, or medical condition. Our public hospitals and emergency rooms are typically overcrowded and booked and are well-known for turning away - especially indigent people with no medical insurance (typical for homeless, poor, or disenfranchised) excerpt for truly immediate and life-threatening conditions and, even then, often well be released prematurely to supposedly “at home care” for longer-term treatment etc.; an option a homeless person does not have.Jail - not really a feasible option at all and an absolutely stupid one for anyone who has no idea what jail really is like.Family, if they have any - often they have left abusive families for a reason; if they were young and still living with their parents or caretakers, often they may have been abused (physical, mental, sexual, or often a combination), or thrown out. If they were adults themselves, typically an adult woman that is married, or had a long-term partner, they were sometimes a domestic violence victim and they escaped/ran away to survive.For some additional background about homeless people. Many people who don’t really know or think about homeless issues may not realize how sadly democratic the homeless population is. Homeless people don’t just include young, able-bodied men. Homeless people include elderly men, elderly women, single women, full families INCLUDING even children and infants, disabled persons, and various different ethnic and cultural backgrounds. Some excerpts from our local NYC Coalition for the Homeless website Basic Facts About Homelessness: New York City - Coalition For The Homeless In September 2016, there were 61,931 homeless people, including 15,691 homeless families with 24,148 homeless children, sleeping each night in the New York City municipal shelter system. Families comprise just over three-quarters of the homeless shelter population. Based on this, a full 39% of the current NYC homeless population are CHILDREN. One question I can’t even attempt to answer is “why is there such a large homeless problem and what can we do about it?” There are so many contributing factors, causes, and issues involved and I frequently still puzzle over the dilemma, this crisis, of homelessness. The plight of the homeless is real, worse than most people can imagine (or understand, including me), and much more horrific at multiple emotional and mental levels than most can accept, at least in the beginning.  ADDED. This from comment to Melinda’s answer, but I think it is relevant point to include about why some homeless people seem to be “proud” about being homeless. Excerpted from my original comment. To be clear, they weren’t proud about suffering as such, but proud about being able to withstand it and become a survivor, a.k.a. somewhat like the old cliche, “what doesn’t kill you, makes you stronger.” It makes them tough, they develop street instincts, hone their sense of alertness and awareness, just generally learn to adapt fast.

Are there homeless people who want to be homeless? Yes. I think there are. I was in a nearby historic park and met a homeless woman living in her car. She stayed with me most of that day. I was there for a reunion and she came along with me. Afterward, she said good bye and went away in her car. A few days later I got a phone call that this “homeless” woman would be moving to my town and could she stay with me a few days until her place was ready. I explained that my house wasn’t ready for visitors (still recovering from tornado damage). She decided she could stay in my driveway in her car. It was more than a week before the call came that her place was ready. In the mean time she decided to “help” me by cutting down my historic plants, and running water under my front porch (mold). I was irked that she was killing so many of my plants. She did get a job but it lasted only a few days and she quit. She claimed she was being harassed by the other workers. She got another job, but complained that the police were following her. She was fired after the first week for ‘making mountains out of mole hills’. She complained that the people in the trailer court where she had been placed were “looking at” her. I had been there- I didn’t get that impression. Then she said she had to leave because the person in the home service office had given her husband her telephone number. In the mean time she asked me for money —a car payment , a new cell phone card. Then she was gone. She didn’t repay the money. A few weeks later I noticed a front window was open. She had been in my house. She left things I recognized that the home service supervisor had given her: pajamas from the recycle shop, flip flops. I slowly noticed that things were missing. An arrowhead that my brother had made before he was killed. A finial was pryed off an antique secretary. And my first edition copy of The Origin of Species had been thrown on the floor with a pile of human feces on it. Other things were broken —as if she had fallen down over them. And there were books that weren’t mine. They were mostly bible stories. Are there people who want to be homeless?. There are people who know the homeless game. They know how to play you so you will help them out — get them a place to live. Steal what you have so they can re=sell it. She as much as told me that she didn’t mind trading sex for dinner and a good night’’s sleep. For some people, homeless is just a game. She was looking for a “fisherman” who would be a good target.

Absolutely. I have been homeless for a better part of the the last 35 years. Why? Experienced homelessness for the first time in 1970, and 4 or 5 times from then, on until 1977. Watched my mother suffer a mental crisis on multiple occasions. The first one caused me and my brothers to be placed in the county juvenile detention facility. Was placed in foster care, and ended up attending over 20 schools from kindergarten up until half way through the 11th grade. (Have names, addresses and phone numbers of all the schools). Anyway, watching what society and the status quo did to my mother (she died shortly after her 59th birthday). Having practical experience of how things like minimum wage can and does lead to homelessness. Well, to make an exceedingly long story short, I chose to be homeless. Why? Excellent question. Here's some of the reasons: Don't have to be stressed about not being able to pay rent. Won't be evicted. Never have to be concerned about home invasion. Won't lose anything in a fire, not worried about having anything of value stolen from me (I have crappy stuff).

I’ve heard it said often that this is true, but I just don’t know. My grandson was involved in a study of homeless teens in our area while in college and it turned out that something like 96% of them DID have homes to go to, but preferred the streets because they didn’t have to deal with parental rules. Who knows the validity of that study…it wasn’t a huge study. I frequently help a homeless man who lives in our area. I started seeing him on the streets more than 10 years ago. Sometimes he looks as if he hasn’t seen a bath in years, but other times he has a fresh haircut, clean clothes and appears to have bathed. I’ve learned over time that he has parents who want him to live with them, but he can’t handle the idea of being cooped up in a house and prefers the streets. I assume the times he appears cleaned up is when his parents are able to convince him to come home and get cleaned up. I’ve also learned that, when he was young, he basically fried his brains on drugs, and really isn’t capable of doing much except sit on a street corner holding a cardboard sign. There have been investigations done in our area of people who stand on street corners and hold signs saying they are homeless and asking for help. They found out that for a large number of these people, this is their employment. They receive donations from people who feel sorry for them but go back to their homes at night knowing they just “earned” enough to support themselves for the day and didn’t have to pay taxes. It seems this is a chosen lifestyle for these people. Because of situations like this, I find it very hard to know how many are actually homeless…and how many are actually in need. It saddens my heart to see someone who looks down and out, BUT I can’t afford to help someone who is scamming me…and those scammers prevent people in real need from getting help. I know drugs and alcohol and mental illness are reasons many people are on the streets, so I think we need to re-institute mental institutions for these people. Not old-style mental institutions where they’re just housed, but places where they are cared for, given drug/alcohol-addition treatment, given the right medications to deal with their mental illness, counseling, and perhaps trained for jobs. Homelessness is such a complicated situation, and frankly, I think it requires a case by case investigation to see what can be done to help the individual.

There actually ARE persons like that. I don’t know if it is MANY. But the few who are definitely like that, are often very visible to everyone. and known to everybody in the area. The reason why they are known about is people know them. Often they have been offered help already and have turned it down. So that is how people know their names. The “Lady of Monte Vista” comes to mind. If you live in Albuquerque you might have heard of her. Because she is like a local legend. She slept on my father's lawn for 10 years. In the winter she slept covered in snow. When it snowed. And she is definitely mentally ill. Hers is not a case of drugs. Once they did haul her in and did a fingerprint scan and she remains unidentified. Definitely no criminal history. It is believed she was raped a lot when a child and is therefore really uncomfortable being behind four walls of any sort. She might associate four walls and a roof with all kinds of horror. That is speculation. The city actually gave her a free apartment. But she left it in 3 days. She is definitely one who doesn’t want help. I mean she will take handouts and stuff but won’t move indoors. And it is not for lack of trying either. She’s got a grip of persons from various walks of life including professionals chasing her down trying to give her more blankets and offers to move to a better climate etc. Now you do have to realize this is a case of mental illness, not drugs. She’d probably rather die then live a standard life, and if people stopped helping she probably WOULD die. It’s not like if they stopped helping she’d finally go to rehab or something like that. So people help. God bless those people If you are reading this and you are one of those people and you for some reason googled “Lady of Monte Vista” God Bless you.

No, most people do not choose to be homeless. Believe me it was not a choice for me or anyone I have met on the streets. Catastrophic events in peoples lives. That is what causes homelessness. Loss of a job. The average person is not prepared with savings and resources to maintain their current living conditions for more than one or two months. The majority of working class people live paycheck to paycheck. Unemployment insurance usually takes a month to begin, if you are found eligible. Even then it wont be enough to pay your bills and you will be lucky if your landlord will work with you.. Medical problems for you or one of your family. Watch the movie “Q” and you will see how quickly you will be faced with losing everything. Say you are on welfare get money for housing. Your landlord dies and the building is up for sale. You have to get out. The amount of time is not enough for you to find a place that will offer you the same arrangement. You too are on the street. Mental health issues? Your family set you up with a motel room and meds after your last hospital stay. Within the first two days you are robbed of everything even your id and meds. There is no inpatient hospital to go to and your meds will not be replaced.

Some people think it’s better than any alternative that is open to them. I knew a women who spoke of her brief time homeless with pride. She didn’t infringe upon the hospitality of her friends, and she didn’t go back to her abusive father with her tail between her legs. She didn’t like having to sleep on the streets, but it was the best option available. This requires a great deal of pride, and I doubt the phenomenon is common, but it happens. When it does happen, it’s almost certainly among people who are only on the streets for a short period of time. Being homeless sucks. Having a character that can be brave in the face of that is admirable, but there’s not anything to enjoy in the experience. The only reason anyone seeks it out is if their situation is so bad that sleeping on a park bench sounds like a better idea in comparison. That involves some pretty severe misfortune no matter how you assess the situation. No one should ever have to make that choice, despite the fact that some people do.

No one chooses to be homeless. No one chooses to sleep on cement, the ground, or in a tent. Who wants to have a bowel movement on the street? Who wants to smell? Who wants to live with the threat of being raped? assaulted ? have rats crawl over your face when you’re sleeping? People become homeless because of mental health issues, abuse situations, or economic reasons.Drugs play a large role in deciding who will be homeless. Does anyone have a goal to become a drug addict?Who wants to lose their dignity and watch the world pass them by? Homeless people lose their joy, their reason to laugh, and a reason to hope. Go into my city in the middle of the night and you’ll see homeless people wandering everywhere, jumping out in front of your car. These folks have been thrown out of society like throwing out the garbage. Every human being has value. Everyone has an epic story to share with the rest of us. Homeless people are living proof more of us need to help our fellow man. Don’t pretend they’re not in front of you, they are.

yes. I stated in a previous post that on the streets I had a purpose to my day and job to do in my community of people. Some days I was a scout looking for new places to sleep any place that may throw out food for my crew to eat. Other days I was keeping tabs on who was in the community using my friendly style to talk to them and my lack of drama to get them to trust me and where they were and if they had any new tips they picked up in their own adventures. I felt satisfied pretty much every day never alone usually had someone watching my back as much as I watched theirs. I was trusted and counted on liked and respected at times even. Ya I did enjoy that and I miss it to this day. I did more then that I have ever since. I really feel close to the story that Tom wrote about the man he knew. I had a great deal of pride in myself for surviving every day and felt powerful and smart knowing what to do and where to go at nearly any time. Lawrence is such a good man and he was able to explain what I struggle now. “I know you ain't trying to do nothing, but I'm alright out here. I don't have much but what I have, I earned. I never begged for nothin’ and I ain't planning to now.”

Over the past 20 years I’ve met quite a few homeless people, individuals and families. I never counted but usually 10 - 15 homeless contacts per week. I have met very few that wanted to be homeless. For nearly all it wasn’t a choice. Of those few that didn’t want to find a place the reasons primarily revolved around a few causes. The most common was that they just couldn't adapt to living in an environment where they had to follow rules. A couple were vets with PTSD and had resigned themselves to avoiding people at nearly all cost. Another was a guy in his late 20’s from a wealthy family who resented his family and all the trappings of wealth that her grew up with. He lived in stairwells, laundry rooms, hallways, etc and was a general nuisance. His family tried to reach out to him from time to time but he continually refused any help. I never met a woman that voluntarily lived in the streets. That’s not to say it doesn’t happen, just that I’ve never met any.

response.answer_text: I don't know if they all chose to be homeless, but it was a choice for me. I had to make a long and hard decision if I wanted to spend what little money I was earning on rent, or on tuition as I went back to college to finish my bachelor's degree. I had a job, so I had an income, and the college had places I could shower, shave and do laundry. I would spend my time in the library studying or in the gym working out, small naps in the student activity center, or watching the local news at a nearby Burger King. Then about five hours of sleep on the streets and I could face the next day. I hated living in the streets, but I'm glad I finished my education and got better paying jobs as a result. But now, homeless-but-employed is becomming more and more common in California. I may have been among one of the first, but I'm most assuredly not the last.

Yes! Many years ago I lived in Hermosa Beach, California. I met a rather remarkable older man. He became a teacher to me. I found out that he was a monk. He told me that he had “gone forth to homelessness”. He said that was the term that was used “in the East” for those who chose the life he had chosen. Apparently, there are spiritual reasons for “choosing” homelessness in some societies. This man was at least 60 years old, but was extremely “fit” and clean. I sometimes saw him meditating on the beach and running along the sand by the water early in the morning. He told me that he had traveled all over the world and studied sacred texts. I can tell you this with certainty: His teachings were remarkable and profound and have sustained me in a spiritual sense for the last 50 years. And in his presence I experienced a transcendental moment that lifted me out of my body and filled me with “music”.

It’s not a lifestyle choice. Nobody in their right mind would choose homelessness but some are clearly not in their right minds. These are the ones that need help. My friend Paul is in my bedroom at the moment; if he wasn’t he’d be on the streets with or without his wheelchair or in a homeless shelter without it. Paul has problems dealing with money so I’ve got access to his bank account. What he really wants is his own place and a life free of money problems. Sticking him in a flat now wouldn’t help, he just wouldn’t be able to cope, get evicted and end up back on the street. You want the truth? Sure some are. It can make you feel incredibly free. I knew a guy once who rode the rails. He wasn’t an alcoholic, he never did drugs. He had even graduated high school. He could’ve gotten out of the life anytime he wanted, but it was the life he had chosen. I would see him a few times a year, his hair mussed by the wind, his face red from the cold and he always looked so happy. He would spend weeks on the train, riding a predetermined route, always with a goal in mind. I have known a lot of people in my life, but I have never again met someone that happy. He’s settled down now, with kids and a wife. But for a few years he was ok being homeless. I guess there were times in the beginning where I was happy, but they were short lived for me. I had a tendency to focus on what I didn’t have, what needed to happen next. I was always planning and it was stressful. Through the years of my drug addiction, that became my sole focus. I always wanted out. But people like my train hopping buddy? They never worry about anything. They move fluidly through the ebb and flow of life, always with optimism. I’ve never been that way. Maybe in the end it’s a good thing. I may have never left the streets if not for my anxiety.

Is it true that homeless people are homeless because they choose to live that way? Absolutely not. While many homeless people are homeless because they want to be, I would say most are not. Most are homeless due to circumstances within and without of their control. I was homeless for a period of about 22 months. In 2003 I had surgery on my low back. It felt so good to be without pain. It was unbelievable … for two whole days. Then I sat up from a lying position and felt a sharp pain. For five years after that, I was in excruciating pain. It finally became too much for me mentally and emotionally, and I burned out at work. That started a slow slide in to homelessness. Eventually the pain more or less dissipated, but it was damn difficult pulling myself out of homelessness. At around my mid-50s no one wanted to hire me in my field (computing). I lost my house, then lost my apartment, then lost my lodgings, and finally ended up in a series of shelters. There were many men I met along the way who were educated and lost everything due to job loss. It was about this time that Mark Zuckerberg said that age 30 is the new 40. Many men in their mid-40s and up lost jobs after the Bush years and were not rehired in their fields. Many people lost their homes that they had worked very hard to maintain. Businesses like Facebook wanted new faces, young faces. Pure and simple age discrimination. Impossible to prove. I ended up working for a large retailer know by their blue and yellow color scheme for less than a third of my previous was. This happened to another guy the I worked with at the big blue retailer.

No. Most homeless people are homeless because their income hasn’t kept up with rising rents. Over 40% of the homeless population is disabled and they are literally priced out of all of the major real estate markets. The waiting list for HUD Sec 8 or Shelter Plus Care vouchers is years long with many of the waiting lists closed, some have been for years. The waiting list for apartments that take Sec 8 can also be years long. One Senior building in my neighborhood has a waiting list that is 5 years long! Not really, no. Of course, there are some who will likely dispute this, claiming that homeless people, if they’d just done X or tried harder at Y they wouldn’t have become homeless. And while that may be true to some extent, it’s a massive oversimplification. I can use myself for an example. I did all the things I could when my disabilities started getting the better of me. I had better than average medical care for a poor person because I was a veteran. I worked as much as I could, but it ended up being less and less. I tried being self-employed so I could set my own hours to work around my disabilities, but couldn’t work enough. I moved in with other people to reduce my expenses. But all the while, my physical health was disintegrating, and my mental health was in an even more rapid decline. Eventually the people I was living with determined that I wasn’t safe to have around them or their kid, so they had little choice but to kick me out. Looking back on past me, I fully agree. But yeah, there are always those who will reply ‘if you just did *this* you never would have been homeless’, to which I generally have to ignore because they don’t have the background to understand what actually happens to people like me.
